Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back crudely marked with clypeus oddly indicated, with single line straight across for prothorax and another for elytra; at side, legs rather well-modelled with deeply undercut triangle; underside decorated with clump of papyrus rising from neb-basket sign; motif possibly carved out instead of stamped; longitudinally pierced; glaze lost, originally yellow, now dull white like core.
Curator's comments: Scarabs with a motif of papyrus’ thicket depicted on the base belong to a standard group produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Petrie illustrated a number of different versions on scarabs and scaraboids (Petrie 1886, pl. 37, 4-7). This type was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 98-99, type XXVIII, subtype A159-166). Note that the motif does not look to be stamped, and the cast technique is a major characteristic of Gorton's type XXVIII. For related motifs on Naukratis scarabs and scaraboids: BM 1888,0601.1605; Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.681; Birmingham City Museum & Art Gallery 1888A195.4; Sydney, The Nicholson Museum, University of Sydney NM00.128.8. Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, 'Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site', in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming, Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 6)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.085) (phase 3)
